Although, I do allow people to raise the priority of the Syncthing process, and I'm reasonably sure that's because someone asked for it. So I'm not sure that avoiding doing this is necessarily the right thing to do.

@AudriusButkevicius 

> The ioprio argument given to ioprio_set() is a bit mask that specifies both the scheduling class and the priority to be assigned to the target process(es). The following macros are used for assembling and dissecting ioprio values:
>
> `IOPRIO_PRIO_VALUE(class, data)`
> Given a scheduling class and priority (data), this macro combines the two values to produce an ioprio value, which is returned as the result of the macro.
> `IOPRIO_PRIO_CLASS(mask)`
> Given mask (an ioprio value), this macro returns its I/O class component, that is, one of the values IOPRIO_CLASS_RT, IOPRIO_CLASS_BE, or IOPRIO_CLASS_IDLE.
> `IOPRIO_PRIO_DATA(mask)`
> Given mask (an ioprio value), this macro returns its priority (data) component.

We'd need to figure out what those macros do and how that bitmask works, replicate it, and hope it never changes... For all of our architectures and bit orders.

Cool. The "avoid to raise" thing is just that if someone already set nice level 19 we should not raise it back to 9 due to `setLowPriority=true`, for example. Because that's the opposite of what our option says and clearly against the user's wishes. But I don't think we need to do much to avoid it...

```
/*
 * Gives us 8 prio classes with 13-bits of data for each class
 */
#define IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT	(13)
#define IOPRIO_PRIO_MASK	((1UL << IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT) - 1)

#define IOPRIO_PRIO_CLASS(mask)	((mask) >> IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT)
#define IOPRIO_PRIO_DATA(mask)	((mask) & IOPRIO_PRIO_MASK)
#define IOPRIO_PRIO_VALUE(class, data)	(((class) << IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT) | data)

#define ioprio_valid(mask)	(IOPRIO_PRIO_CLASS((mask)) != IOPRIO_CLASS_NONE)

/*
 * These are the io priority groups as implemented by CFQ. RT is the realtime
 * class, it always gets premium service. BE is the best-effort scheduling
 * class, the default for any process. IDLE is the idle scheduling class, it
 * is only served when no one else is using the disk.
 */
enum {
	IOPRIO_CLASS_NONE,
	IOPRIO_CLASS_RT,
	IOPRIO_CLASS_BE,
	IOPRIO_CLASS_IDLE,
};

/*
 * 8 best effort priority levels are supported
 */
#define IOPRIO_BE_NR	(8)

enum {
	IOPRIO_WHO_PROCESS = 1,
	IOPRIO_WHO_PGRP,
	IOPRIO_WHO_USER,
};
```

Just a few comments on this:

1. The classes you listed are how Linux implements things, I'm not sure that it's the same on other UNIX systems, and it might be good to double check for at least FreeBSD (the other BSD's should be similar enough to FreeBSD to not matter).
2. IO class is by default set by the process scheduling class on pretty much all UNIX systems in existence.  For Linux for example, if you set a process's nice value to 20, it will automatically get the lowest best-effort scheduling class for I/O, set it to -19 and it will automatically get the highest best-effort class, set it to real-time scheduling, it will get a RT I/O scheduling class of appropriate proportionate value, and set to the idle CPU scheduling class and it will get the idle I/O scheduling class.
3. The 'idle' scheduling classes on Linux aren't actual idle schedulers, they will still preempt other things on occasion, they just get the lowest possible scheduling priority (which is good on the CPU side, but probably bad on the I/O side for most people as it will increase the time it takes to actually sync things).
4. Only some schedulers on Linux actually support I/O priorities handled this way.  Some don't support priorities at all, others only support them through control groups.  I would be very careful about how this change of priority is documented, as otherwise you will get people complaining about it having no impact on anything on distros that use such schedulers by default (which is most big distros right now actually).

My obvious approach didn't work because the available APIs are thread based and we don't control threading. I suspect another possibly valid approach would be to do it in the monitor process as part of launching the real process. Obvious drawbacks with that approach though.
I thought there were flags to apply it per thread or per process group, in which case all threads get marked.
If so I didn't find them.

Right, that actually does work for Linux, which I didn't think it would. ("Process" is supposed to cover it, but Linux isn't POSIX compliant.) It's still not the case for Windows though, which is arguably where it's more needed.

Windows has two calls, one per process and one for threads. End result is base value for process + value for the thread for each thread. We just need to drop the priority for the process and that's it.
